title: Awareness: The Center That Heals
excerpt: Today’s reflections began as a quiet curiosity about control, why the human mind longs to control everything, and why that desire seems to make us more fragile.
content:
Today’s reflections began as a quiet curiosity about control, why the human mind longs to control everything, and why that desire seems to make us more fragile.

As I followed that thought, I began to see how ego, fear, and desire form an inseparable triad, each one feeding and protecting the others.

The ego wants to define itself, to be certain of who it is. Fear arises whenever that identity feels threatened. Desire emerges as the effort to fill what feels missing — power, love, peace, or validation. Together they create a loop that keeps the mind restless, always chasing or resisting something.

I realised that the key isn’t to destroy these parts but to become aware of them, to see the loop instead of spinning inside it. The more we try to control life, the more we’re controlled by our need for control.

But when we rest in awareness, we discover a still center, a space between fear and desire where ego softens.
It feels like levitating in the middle of the triad, not above life, but free within it.

This awareness isn’t cold detachment; it’s living clarity. From that center, I can watch ego’s voice without obeying it, witness fear without shrinking, feel desire without being consumed. Awareness becomes a gentle light, revealing rather than fighting.

Then I understood how this connects to addiction and trauma.
When awareness is lost, the unseen drives us. Addiction isn’t only a craving for pleasure but often a search for relief, a way to escape fear, shame, or loneliness. The power of the addiction lies in the lack of awareness; what’s unconscious rules by default.

I thought of a young boy, introduced to sexual experience far too early, before he knew himself. What began as confusion later became shame, then a hidden compulsion, and finally addiction. That story showed me how early violations of innocence fracture awareness: the child’s sense of self, safety, and control are torn apart. The adult then wrestles not only with desire, but with unhealed pain.

Yet even there, healing begins the same way, with awareness.
Not harsh judgment, not suppression, but seeing clearly and compassionately:

“This is pain seeking understanding.
This is fear seeking safety.
This is desire seeking wholeness.”

To see is to begin freeing what once “possessed” us.
In spiritual terms, demons lose power in light.
In psychological terms, the shadow loses power when it’s owned and integrated.
In both, awareness is redemption.

Awareness doesn’t erase the past, but it transforms the relationship to it. The boy, the fear, the craving — they all become parts of a larger self that can finally breathe.

Healing, then, is not about becoming pure, but about becoming whole.

Tonight, I understand that awareness is not a distant goal; it is the path itself. Every moment I notice without running, every breath that meets emotion with kindness, is an act of liberation.

I do not fight my shadows; I bring them into light.
What once ruled me loses power in my awareness.
I am learning to rest in the still center, free, whole, and awake.

title: The Number Not Taken
excerpt: I asked for a doorway, your number, a chance to knock, to learn the shape of your voice without rushing its echo.
content:
I asked for a doorway,  
your number,  
a chance to knock,  
to learn the shape of your voice  
without rushing its echo.  

---

But you asked me  
for a vow at the threshold—  
not a hello,  
but a devotion  
I could not yet name.  

---

How do I promise forever  
to a stranger?  
How do I swear a covenant  
before I’ve heard you laugh,  
before I’ve seen if silence  
feels heavy or holy between us?  

---

I could have lied.  
If my motive were hunger,  
if my fire were only flesh,  
you would have believed me.  
And maybe you would have  
handed me the key,  
thinking yourself guarded  
while leaving the gate wide open.  

---

This stance—  
noble in dream,  
but fragile in practice—  
makes you a lantern unshielded,  
an easy target for the wind  
of men with silver tongues.  

---

So I left the truth plain:  
I cannot promise devotion  
to someone I do not know.  
But I will not dress wolves  
in sheep’s language  
to earn an audience.  

---

Better the door stay closed  
than opened by deceit.

title: The Riverwalk we Never Took
content:
I set the table in my mind
before the table was ever set.
A place by the river,
a glass raised to reflection,
a meal dressed in candlelight.
And between the sip and the plate,
a walk—
just a walk—
to let the night breathe with us,
to hear the water speak
what words cannot.

But the word betrayed me.
Walk.
She heard it as insult,
as if I’d traded velvet for gravel,
as if the river itself
was not enough.
Anger spilled where wine should have,
high horses trampling the evening
before it ever began.
Luxury to her—
basic to me.
A mirror we could not share.

I could have flared,
but I knew the wound
that lent her voice its flame.
I’ve seen the places
where insecurity sharpens its teeth.
So I stood still.
Not angry.
Not small.
Just certain.

The restaurant remained untouched.
The river kept its silence.
And I—
I kept my lamp,
choosing not to burn
in a fire I did not light.

title: Echo of the Lamp
content:
I touched gold,
and thought it glittered like everything else.
Didn’t know real had weight—
until your absence crushed the air.

You gave me light
and I shaded my eyes.
Not because I hated the glow,
but because it asked me to see.

You were not loud,
but you were clarity
and that terrified me.

I named your grace “too much,”
because I wasn’t enough
to hold it without trembling.

Now, silence speaks louder
than all the noise I once mistook for love.
Now, your lamp
the one you left behind
flickers in my memory.

Not to guilt me,
but to remind me:
Real doesn’t beg to be seen.
It just is.

You walked away
without slamming doors.
That’s how I knew
you were the truth.

And I
I was the frame
that couldn't carry the painting.

But I see it now.

Thank you
for not blowing out the flame

title: Epiphany of a Bridge
content:
I am the bridge spanning fire and water
Caught between extremes, I falter
As steam rises from their fierce clash
I must contain them, a delicate task

But I refuse to see this as my new norm
I've had an epiphany, a thought reborn
Realizing that everything is a state of mind
I now face the challenge with a different kind

No longer burdened by the weight of extremes
I let go of fear and broken dreams
Embracing the role I was meant to play
As a bridge, guiding the way

So let the fire and water rage
For I will stand strong and engage
A conduit between two forces great
Finding balance in their opposing fate

Reflection
This piece came from a moment of clarity: the realization that we are not trapped between extremes, but positioned to hold them both.

The bridge isn’t fragile, even if it trembles; it exists to connect.

The steam isn’t chaos, it’s transformation.

And balance isn’t about silencing fire or drowning it in water, but standing in the tension, unbroken.

Sometimes our role is not to choose sides, but to become the passage where both can meet.

Closing Thought
We all carry fire and water within us. Some days, they war. Some days, they harmonize. But the bridge remains.

What extremes are you standing between right now and how might it change things if you saw yourself as the bridge, not the battleground?

If this piece resonates, consider subscribing — I’ll be sharing more poems and reflections that live at the meeting point of spirit, story, and self.

title: The Weight of knowing
excerpt: The older I get, the clearer it becomes: how frail life is. The more I know, the more I realise how foolish I was yesterday. Sometimes, when my heart grows heavy under the burden of knowing, I'm tempted to pick up a stick and scrawl upon the sands of time that old saying: "Ignorance is bliss." Though I know the tide will claim it, I still fight the urge for it is a soft escape, a temporary peace with a lasting cost. The older I get, the more I treasure the wisdom of elders, the stories of their failings, and the grace found even in their imperfections
content:
The older I get,
the clearer it becomes:
how frail life is.

The more I know,
the more I realise
how foolish I was yesterday.

Sometimes, when my heart grows heavy
under the burden of knowing,
I'm tempted to pick up a stick
and scrawl upon the sands of time
that old saying:
"Ignorance is bliss."

Though I know the tide will claim it,
I still fight the urge
for it is a soft escape,
a temporary peace
with a lasting cost.

The older I get,
the more I treasure
the wisdom of elders,
the stories of their failings,
and the grace found
even in their imperfections

title: Counterfeit Connoisseur
excerpt: I heard my heart tell my hand, he’s got a lot to let out. This time, my hand is gonna do the talking so he picked up the pen and wrote. “What should we even write about?” he asked. Just write. This is more than a conversation It's a map to finding you. Where have you been? Where are you hiding? Are you buried beneath the weight of all you should’ve been? WAKE UP. I gave gold to the blind to treasure. I never knew I was dealing with a Counterfeit Connoisseur. No lies they are beautifully made, just like me. A little flawed, being human, just like me. I dared to hope that, perhaps, one day even you, Counterfeit Connoisseur, will feel the weight of what is real. Let sight return when absence echoes louder than the clamor of ego. I took back what is rare but I never unlit the lamp. Let it flicker behind a mercy you may never know.
content:
I heard my heart tell my hand,
he’s got a lot to let out.
This time, my hand is gonna do the talking

so he picked up the pen and wrote.
“What should we even write about?” he asked.
Just write.

This is more than a conversation
It's a map to finding you.
Where have you been?
Where are you hiding?
Are you buried beneath the weight
of all you should’ve been?

WAKE UP.

I gave gold to the blind to treasure.
I never knew I was dealing with
a Counterfeit Connoisseur.

No lies
they are beautifully made,
just like me.

A little flawed,
being human,
just like me.

I dared to hope that, perhaps,
one day
even you, Counterfeit Connoisseur,
will feel the weight
of what is real.

Let sight return
when absence echoes
louder than the clamor of ego.

I took back what is rare
but I never unlit the lamp.

Let it flicker
behind a mercy
you may never know.

title: When I Was Younger
excerpt: When I was younger, I wanted to change the world. I began to ask questions, simulating ways to make humans do what is right and hate what’s wrong. But one question led to another: Do I even know what’s right? And what’s wrong? I wanted to force them, but I realised, humans are strong-willed. No force can truly change the world. Later, I resolved to this answer: Love. I said, I would change the world with love. I tried. And as I grew, I met many broken Some nearly broke me. I almost forgot what I said I would do. But one thing I always do: I try to leave a light in their dark. Not so huge, but strong enough to last till the end of time. Some days, that light flickers in me too. Some nights, I need the very spark I gave away. And yet even when I’m tired, even when I’m lost in thought, I remember: I was never here to conquer them, only to touch them. Not to shout truth, but to live it quietly, until it speaks for itself. And if I leave no statue, no sound, no echo loud enough to fill a room let me leave a warmth that lingers in the silence. That, To me, Is still Changing the world.
content:
When I was younger,
I wanted to change the world.
I began to ask questions,
simulating ways to make humans
do what is right
and hate what’s wrong.

But one question led to another:
Do I even know what’s right?
And what’s wrong?

I wanted to force them,
but I realised,
humans are strong-willed.
No force can truly change the world.

Later,
I resolved to this answer:
Love.

I said,
I would change the world with love.

I tried.
And as I grew,
I met many broken
Some nearly broke me.

I almost forgot
what I said I would do.

But one thing I always do:
I try to leave a light
in their dark.
Not so huge,
but strong enough
to last till the end of time.

Some days,
that light flickers in me too.
Some nights,
I need the very spark I gave away.

And yet
even when I’m tired,
even when I’m lost in thought,
I remember:

I was never here to conquer them,
only to touch them.
Not to shout truth,
but to live it quietly,
until it speaks for itself.

And if I leave no statue,
no sound,
no echo loud enough to fill a room
let me leave a warmth
that lingers in the silence.

That,
To me,
Is still
Changing the world.
